awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Functional Morphology and Macroevolution of the Mammalian Cervical Vertebral Column
awd_abstract_narration:
Bipedal locomotion is a hallmark trait of the human evolutionary lineage, representing a major transition away from the apes and other primates. This pivotal shift can be investigated through studies of the neck, as the human neck is adapted to balance and stabilize the head during bipedal movements. This doctoral research project will test how the shape of the bones of the neck relate to locomotion and posture in a diverse sample of mammals. The findings will be used to interpret fossilized neck bones from extinct human relatives to learn about their early forms of bipedalism, as well as potentially informing clinical research. This project will also support the sharing of three-dimensional scan data through digital repositories and the training and mentorship of student researchers, including those from groups underrepresented in scientific fields. 

Cervical vertebrae in the hominin fossil record can provide insight into the interplay between the head, neck and trunk during key locomotor and postural transitions. Currently, however, functional interpretations of these fossils are limited to broad categories such as "human-like" neck mobility or "ape-like" neck posture. The goal of this dissertation is to improve hominin neck reconstructions by experimentally testing how cervical vertebral shape relates to neck function, locomotor mode, and trunk posture. This goal will be addressed in three objectives: 1) quantify the relationship between vertebral shape and neck mobility using bending mechanics experiments, 2) develop neck posture models in living species using virtual reconstruction methods, and 3) evaluate patterns of vertebral shape change across diverse mammalian groups using phylogenetic comparative methods. The objectives will be tested in a broad sample of primates, rodents, and marsupials. These groups contain species with independently-evolved forms of bipedal locomotion and upright trunk posture, allowing for independent verification of form-function relationships. This project will provide the foundational data necessary to quantitatively interpret functional information from cervical vertebral fossils, furthering our understanding of the nature and biomechanical demands of bipedalism in early hominins.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In mammals, the neck plays an important role in stabilizing and moving the head. Humans have evolved unique necks compared to other living mammals, as we use our necks to balance the head above an upright trunk while striding on two legs (bipedalism). Studying the evolution of the human neck may therefore provide insights into the evolution of behaviors that are unique to our lineage. Here, we used new statistical tests and a broadly comparative sample to model patterns of neck evolution in mammals. The results reveal how behavior can be inferred from the anatomy of the neck and the base of the skull, with implications for tracing key behavioral changes in the human lineage.

This research focused on the vertebrae of the lower neck and upper trunk (the fifth cervical vertebra through the first thoracic vertebra) as well as the structures on the base of the skull that articulate with the neck (the occipital condyles). Bony shape was measured using three-dimensional landmarks as well as linear metrics in a broadly comparative sample of living species from the primate, rodent, and marsupial mammal groups. The living species in the sample exhibit diverse behaviors, including several instances of shared behaviors that were evolved independently, allowing for powerful testing of form-function links. Four extinct hominin species (Homo neanderthalensis, Australopithecus sediba, Australopithecus afarensis, and Paranthropus robustus) and five extinct plesiadapiforms (Plesiadapis cookei, Nannodectes intermedius, Nannodectes gidleyi, Plesiadapis tricuspidens, and Pronothodectes gaoi) were also included. Phylogenetically-informed statistics were used to test whether vertebral shape is significantly impacted by a species’ locomotion (for example, habitually moving on four legs or on two legs), substrate use (for example, habitually living in the trees or on the ground), and trunk posture (habitually using an upright or horizontal trunk posture). The results provide the most broadly comparative study of multidimensional neck evolution in mammals to date.

As predicted, three-dimensional vertebral shape reflected locomotor mode, substrate, and to a lesser degree, trunk posture. In general, locomotor mode had the largest relative impact on three-dimensional shape and accounts for the highest amount of shape variation. For example, species that move on two legs had significantly differently shaped vertebrae than species that move on four legs. Species that live in trees had significantly different vertebral shapes than species that live on the ground, and these differences appear to be driven by adaptations required for life in the trees. Trunk posture only had an impact on three-dimensional shape at the first thoracic vertebral level. However, there was a great deal of overlap in three-dimensional shape among groups that use different behaviors. 

When two-dimensional linear shape variables were analyzed individually, significant shifts were found among positional behavioral groups, but these differences were slight. For example, species that live in the trees were found to have generally larger vertebral features than species that live on the ground, as predicted. These vertebral features may be adaptations for the more rapid forms of movement required while moving around unstable, variable arboreal environments. Trunk posture was again associated with changes in linear shape metrics at the first thoracic vertebra, particularly the width of the vertebral centrum in the predicted direction. 

When evolutionary modeling methods were used to track vertebral shape changes over millions of years of primate, rodent, and marsupial evolution, a few individual species exhibited statistically distinct trajectories. However, overall, groups with shared postural, locomotor, and substrate behaviors were not flagged as distinct. 

Together, the results indicate that cervical vertebral shape does differ among groups that navigate the world in distinct ways, but the differences are subtle in scale and may be rapidly adaptable over evolutionary time. Still, the results identified specific shape metrics that were consistently linked to behaviors (for example, detecting posture signals in the width of the first thoracic vertebra) as well as metrics that did not have any support for behavioral signals. Based on the results, caution is warranted when attempting to infer behaviors from the fossilized necks of mammalian species. 

This project provided scientific training and mentorship opportunities for seven undergraduate students who processed micro-CT scan data, landmarked three-dimensional surface files, and presented scientific ideas to the general public. Four of these students were women in STEM, and one was a member of a historically underrepresented minority group in STEM. Three of the students went on to join STEM PhD programs, and two went on to medical school. Additionally, the Co-PI created research protocols that have already been shared with researchers across multiple institutions. The results also have clinical transformative potential, as they may be useful in providing insights into the utility of non-human species for clinical research based on vertebral shape similarities. Lastly, this work has resulted in large quantities of open-source 3D data for use by future scientists.
